contentBlocks.heading: Everyone has a duty to act
contentBlocks.body: All SCL staff must stay alert to abnormalities, immediately report suspected incidents, and complete required training each year. You never need permission to escalate within your chain or to ECS/PSA when you suspect malicious activity.

contentBlocks.heading: Immediate actions
items: Observe and preserve: note time, system, reporter, and visible impact.
Report promptly to ECS/PSA and your supervisor; use the 15-minute escalation rule if no response.
Avoid speculation in email/chat; use approved bridges and evidence-handling guidance.

contentBlocks.heading: Golden Hour mindset
contentBlocks.body: Critical or reportable events must be escalated inside 60 minutes. Early notification enables containment and regulatory timelines.

questions.prompt: What is every staff member expected to do when they notice an abnormal OT condition?
options: Wait for a manager to schedule a meeting
Report it immediately to ECS/PSA and their supervisor
Try to fix it silently to avoid alarms
Post about it on social media

questions.prompt: How often must SCL staff complete CSIR-related training?

contentBlocks.heading: Key terms
contentBlocks.body: Cyber Event: any observable change. Attempt to Compromise (AtC): an intentional attempt to violate security. Cyber Security Incident: a malicious event that jeopardizes confidentiality, integrity, or availability. Reportable Cyber Security Incident: a confirmed incident that meets regulator thresholds (e.g., BES impact, loss of monitoring, OT disruption).

contentBlocks.heading: Intent matters
items: Accidental misconfigurations may be incidents but usually are not reportable unless they impair reliability or security.
AtCs are reportable to regulators by the next business day even if unsuccessful.
Reportable incidents must be elevated within one hour of determination.

contentBlocks.heading: When unsure, treat as suspicious
contentBlocks.body: Escalate to ECS/PSA; they can assist with triage and reportability decisions.

questions.prompt: Which statement about an Attempt to Compromise (AtC) is correct?
options: It is only reportable if it takes down a system
It is reportable by the next business day even if blocked
It is logged but never reported
It only applies to IT systems

questions.prompt: What differentiates a Cyber Security Incident from a generic Cyber Event?
options: Incidents are accidental and events are intentional
Incidents jeopardize confidentiality, integrity, or availability
Events are always more severe than incidents

contentBlocks.heading: Severity guidance
rows: Safety, OT reliability, or public impact is at risk.
BES outage risk, control center loss, ransomware on OT
Major IT disruption or credible threat to operations.
AD compromise, widespread phishing with access
Single asset malware, contained credential theft

contentBlocks.heading: How to use severities
items: Critical and High events start immediate bridges and rapid escalation.
Medium may proceed during business hours but must be logged and monitored.
Low keeps watch-list visibility; adjust if new evidence appears.

options: Multiple failed logins on a kiosk
Loss of OT monitoring screens in a control center

contentBlocks.heading: Phases aligned to NIST
items: Preparation: maintain contacts, playbooks, access to OT sites.
Identification: confirm indicators, classify severity, notify ECS/PSA.
Containment, Eradication, Recovery: protect people and reliability first; choose short-term containment that preserves evidence.
Lessons Learned: capture timelines, DOE-417 references, and playbook updates.

contentBlocks.heading: Notification spans phases
contentBlocks.body: Notification begins during identification and continues as containment decisions are made. Use 15-minute escalation if responders do not acknowledge.

options: During identification and updated through containment

contentBlocks.heading: Core roles
items: Incident Commander: directs strategy, assigns owners, clears communications.
Incident Technical Lead: leads investigation, isolation steps, and evidence preservation.
Enterprise Cyber Security: monitors detections, coordinates reporting, recommends containment, interfaces with CISA/E-ISAC.
NERC-CIP Compliance Leads: map reportability, steward DOE-417 drafts, ensure evidence chain.
CSIR Team Members: execute playbooks, log actions, and validate recovery.
Operations/Asset Owner: confirm safe, reliable operation and approve OT actions.

questions.prompt: Who owns investigation and containment steps?
Who ensures CIP mapping and DOE-417 handling?

contentBlocks.heading: Authority to report
contentBlocks.body: Any reporter can elevate to ECS/PSA without waiting for a meeting. ECS/PSA can file regulatory notifications while the bridge continues.

contentBlocks.heading: Timelines
items: Reportable Cyber Security Incident: notify regulators within one hour of determination.
Attempt to Compromise: notify by the next business day.
Use DOE-417 for reportable OT events; store drafts in the secure ECS repository.

contentBlocks.heading: Who to contact
items: Escalate to ECS/PSA and duty leadership first; apply the 15-minute escalation rule.
Regulator delivery: E-ISAC, CISA Central, SOC emails; confirm by phone when possible.
Encourage phone confirmation for critical submissions to reduce ambiguity.

questions.prompt: How quickly must a reportable cyber security incident be notified to regulators?

steps.title: Safety first & CIP mapping
steps.subtitle: Operate safely and map to CIP

contentBlocks.heading: Safety principle
contentBlocks.body: Safe, secure, reliable operation is the top priority. If a containment action conflicts with grid or site safety, contact the Asset Owner immediately and coordinate a safe alternative.

contentBlocks.heading: CIP mapping (appendix)
items: CIP-008 incident reporting aligns with CSIR reporting timelines and DOE-417 use.
CIP-007 logging/monitoring requirements feed identification and evidence preservation.
CIP-010 change management applies to containment and recovery changes.

questions.prompt: If a containment step risks reliability, what should you do?
options: Pause and consult the Asset Owner for a safe alternative
